questions.question: A company has been assigned the network 172.20.0.0/16 and needs to create 30 separate subnets for different departments while maximizing the number of hosts per subnet. What subnet mask should they use?
questions.explanation: Using /21 provides 32 subnets (2^5 = 32) which meets the requirement of 30 subnets, while leaving 11 host bits for 2046 hosts per subnet. /22 would only give 16 subnets, while /20 and /19 provide fewer hosts per subnet unnecessarily.

questions.question: Why would a network administrator choose to use the 10.0.0.0/8 private address range instead of 192.168.0.0/16 for a large enterprise network?
options: 10.x addresses provide more available IP addresses for hosts
10.x addresses are more secure than 192.168.x addresses
10.x addresses work better with IPv6 dual-stack configurations
questions.explanation: The 10.0.0.0/8 range provides approximately 16.7 million addresses (24 host bits), while 192.168.0.0/16 only provides about 65,000 addresses (16 host bits). For large enterprises with many devices, the 10.x range offers much more addressing space.

questions.question: An organization receives the IPv6 prefix 2001:db8:abcd::/48 from their ISP. They need to create 256 subnets for their campus network. What would be the appropriate subnet prefix length?
questions.explanation: Starting with /48, they need 8 more bits to create 256 subnets (2^8 = 256). Adding 8 bits to the /48 gives /56. This leaves 8 bits for subnetting and maintains the standard /64 for host addressing when further subdivided.

questions.question: A network technician discovers that devices on subnet 192.168.1.0/24 cannot communicate with devices on 192.168.2.0/24, even though both subnets are connected to the same switch. What is the most likely cause of this connectivity issue?
options: The switch ports are configured for different VLANs
The subnets are using different subnet masks
A router is needed because the devices are on different networks
The 192.168.x addresses are conflicting with public internet addresses
questions.explanation: Devices on different IP networks (192.168.1.0/24 vs 192.168.2.0/24) cannot communicate directly even if physically connected to the same switch. Layer 3 routing is required to forward packets between different IP networks.

questions.question: When designing a network that needs to support both IPv4 and IPv6, why might an administrator avoid using the 192.168.0.0/24 subnet specifically?
options: It conflicts with common home router default configurations
It cannot be properly mapped to IPv6 address space
It has insufficient addresses for dual-stack requirements
It is not a valid private IP range for enterprise use
questions.explanation: Many consumer routers use 192.168.0.0/24 or 192.168.1.0/24 by default. Using these ranges in enterprise networks can create conflicts when employees connect VPN clients from home networks using the same addressing scheme, causing routing issues.
